sections.summary: The text notes the defeat of the **Romans** in a nearby land and predicts their subsequent victory within a few years. This historical event serves to demonstrate that **Divine Support** and the ultimate command belong to Allah.

Many people focus on the external aspects of the **worldly life** while neglecting the reality of the **Hereafter**. Allah urges reflection on the fate of previous nations who were more powerful but were destroyed for their **wrongdoing** and rejection of divine signs.

Allah **originates creation** and will repeat it, returning all for a final reckoning. On the Day the Hour occurs, the guilty will despair and be separated from their **partners**, while those who believed and worked righteousness will find delight in meadows.

Believers are instructed to **glorify Allah** during the evening, morning, midday, and night. His power is manifested in the cycle of nature, as He brings the **living out of the dead** and the dead out of the living, illustrating the certainty of the **resurrection** [505–506].

A series of signs are presented to those who reflect, including the creation of humans from dust, the provision of **mates for tranquility**, and the diversity of **languages and colors**. Allah holds the heavens and earth at His disposal, asserting His role as the one who **initiates and repeats creation**.

sections.theme: Fitrah and the Error of Shirk
sections.summary: A parable regarding the status of servants and masters highlights the irrationality of **shirk** (associating partners with Allah). Mankind is called to adhere to the **upright religion**, which is the natural instinct (**fitrah**) Allah has instilled in humanity [506–507].

Humanity is critiqued for calling upon Allah in affliction but lapsing into **ingratitude** when given mercy. The text commands the fulfillment of the rights of the needy and warns that while **usury** does not multiply wealth with Allah, **charity** acts as a true multiplier.

Corruption has emerged on land and sea due to human actions, serving as a warning for people to **return** to righteousness. Believers must commit themselves to the **upright religion** before the arrival of a Day from Allah that cannot be averted.

Winds are described as heralds of **mercy** that drive clouds to revive dead land, serving as a sign of Allah’s ability to **revive the dead**. Despite the rejection faced by past messengers, Allah supports the believers and warns that those who choose **blindness** cannot be guided [508–509].

Humanity is reminded of their development from **weakness** to strength and back to weakness and gray hair. On the Day of Resurrection, sinners will feel they tarried only an hour, and the surah concludes with a command for **patience** because the promise of Allah is true.
